Heading.TitleText: Detection of Fugitive Emissions and Repair Program

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3) and section 8.14, a comprehensive inspection for fugitive emissions at an upstream oil and gas facility must be conducted

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a Type 1 facility, once in each quarter of the calendar year, at least 60 days after the date of the most recent comprehensive inspection; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a Type 2 facility, once per calendar year, at least 270 days after the date of the most recent comprehensive inspection.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an inactive facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an upstream oil and gas facility that begins operations before January 1, 2028, at which crude oil is produced and at which during the previous calendar year

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the volume of crude oil produced did not exceed 600 m3, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the combined volume of hydrocarbon gas produced and received did not exceed 12 000 m3.

Subsection.Text: A comprehensive inspection is not required to be conducted at a Type 1 facility in a quarter of the calendar year if, on the day before the scheduled day of the inspection in that quarter, the temperature at the facility’s location is forecast to be below -20°C on that scheduled day.

A comprehensive inspection must be conducted using an optical gas-imaging instrument that meets the requirements of subsection (5) or any other instrument that meets the requirements of subsection (6).
If a comprehensive inspection is conducted using an optical gas-imaging instrument, the instrument must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of imaging gas that is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the spectral range for the compound of highest concentration in the hydrocarbon gas to be measured, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: composed of half methane and half propane at a total concentration of 500 ppmv or at a flow rate of 60 g/h when it is leaking from an orifice that is 0.635 cm in diameter; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be operated and maintained in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations or, if they are not available, industry standards and best practices.

Subsection.Text: If a comprehensive inspection is conducted using an instrument other than an optical gas-imaging instrument, the instrument must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of measuring 500 ppmv of hydrocarbon;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have a scale that is readable to ±12.5 ppmv of hydrocarbon; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be operated and maintained in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations or, if they are not available, industry standards and best practices.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2) and section 8.14, a screening inspection for fugitive emissions at an upstream oil and gas facility must be conducted once in each month in which the operator or a representative of the operator visits the facility.
A screening inspection is not required to be conducted in any of the following months:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a month in which a comprehensive inspection is conducted at the facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a month in which, on the day before the scheduled day of the screening inspection, the temperature at the facility’s location is forecast to be below -20°C on that scheduled day.

Subsection.Text: A screening inspection must be conducted using a monitoring instrument that, when operated in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations, is capable of detecting a fugitive emission with a flow rate of 10 kg/h or more.
Subject to subsection (3) and section 8.14, an annual inspection for fugitive emissions at an upstream oil and gas facility must be conducted by an auditor who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is independent of the operator and owner of the facility that is to be inspected; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has knowledge of and experience with emission detection instruments.

Subsection.Text: The annual inspection must be conducted in each calendar year at least 180 days after the date of the most recent annual inspection and at least 30 days after the date of the most recent comprehensive inspection.
An annual inspection is not required to be conducted in any calendar year in which an annual inspection is conducted at the upstream oil and gas facility under subsection 53.1(1).
An annual inspection must be conducted using a method that, under standard conditions, provides a 90% or greater probability of detecting a fugitive emission that has a flow rate of 10 kg/h or more.

Section.Text: An inspection required under any of sections 8.1 to 8.12 must be conducted

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by a person who, not more than five years before the day on which the inspection occurs, has received training in the calibration, maintenance and operation of the instruments that are used to conduct the inspection; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: using instruments that are calibrated, maintained and operated in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations, if any.

Section.Text: An inspection required under any of sections 8.1 to 8.12 is not required to include the inspection of an equipment component if that inspection would pose a serious risk to human health or safety.

Subsection.Text: When a fugitive emission is detected at an upstream oil and gas facility, whether as a result of an inspection or otherwise, the equipment component that is emitting the hydrocarbon gas must be repaired

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the repair can be carried out while the equipment component is operating, within the applicable period referred to in subsection (2) or (3); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, before the end of the next planned shutdown of the facility.

Subsection.Text: If the equipment component can be repaired while it is operating and the flow rate of the fugitive emission is not determined, the component must be repaired within 24 hours after the emission is detected.
If the equipment component can be repaired while it is operating and the flow rate of the fugitive emission is determined, the component must be repaired

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flow rate that is less than 1 kg/h, within 90 days after the day on which the emission is detected;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flow rate that is 1 kg/h or more but less than 10 kg/h, within 30 days after the day on which the emission is detected;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flow rate that is 10 kg/h or more but less than 100 kg/h, within seven days after the day on which the emission is detected; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flow rate that is 100 kg/h or more, within 24 hours after the emission is detected.

Subsection.Text: However, if a measure is taken that reduces the flow rate of the fugitive emission to less than 10 kg/h during the applicable repair period referred to in paragraph (3)(c) or (d), the repair must be completed within 30 days after the day on which the emission is detected.
In subsections (6) and (7), a reference to a volume of hydrocarbon gas is a reference to that volume expressed in standard m3.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Deferral of repair — low level emissions
Subsection.Text: Despite paragraphs (3)(a) and (b) and subsection (4), if the equipment component is emitting hydrocarbon gas at a flow rate of less than 10 kg/h, the repair of the equipment component may be deferred until the day on which the estimated total volume of fugitive emissions that, beginning on the day on which the fugitive emission is detected, would be emitted from that equipment component and from all other equipment components as of that day is equal to the volume of hydrocarbon gas that, if none of those equipment components were repaired, would be emitted during a temporary depressurization of the equipment or a pipeline conducted in order to carry out the repair.

If the equipment component cannot be repaired while it is operating, the next planned shutdown of the upstream oil and gas facility must be scheduled no later than the day on which the estimated total volume of fugitive emissions that, beginning on the day on which the fugitive emission is detected, would be emitted from that equipment component and from all other equipment components as of that day is equal to the volume of hydrocarbon gas that, if none of those equipment components were repaired, would be emitted during a temporary depressurization of the equipment or a pipeline conducted in order to carry out the repair.

An equipment component is considered to be repaired when the fugitive emission is no longer detectable using a method that is capable of detecting hydrocarbon gas at a flow rate of 60 g/h or less or at a concentration of 500 ppmv or less.

The operator of an upstream oil and gas facility may apply to the Minister to extend the repair period referred to in paragraph 8.15(3)(a) or (b) or subsection 8.15(4) or, in the case where the repair has been deferred in accordance with subsection 8.15(6), to extend the period to complete the repair, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they make the application at least 15 days before the day on which the repair period ends or the day to which the repair has been deferred, as the case may be; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment component is emitting hydrocarbon gas at a flow rate of less than 10 kg/h.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an upstream oil and gas facility may apply to the Minister to defer the scheduled day of the next planned shutdown of the facility determined in accordance with subsection 8.15(7) if they make the application at least 15 days before that scheduled day.
An application made under subsection (1) or (2) must contain the information referred to in Schedule 1 and the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an application made under subsection (1), documents that establish that, as of the making of the application, there are reasonable grounds to conclude that it is not technically feasible for the operator to complete the repair of the equipment component before the end of the applicable repair period or the day to which the repair has been deferred, as the case may be;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an application made under subsection (2), documents that establish that, as of the making of the application, there are reasonable grounds to conclude that it is not technically feasible for the operator to complete the repair of the equipment component before the end of the next planned shutdown of the upstream oil and gas facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: documents that establish that the operator has a plan to repair the equipment component that sets out

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the expected date for the completion of the repair,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the measures to be taken to ensure completion of the repair on or before that date,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a justification, with supporting documents, for the belief as to why that date is the earliest feasible date to complete the repair, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the measures to be taken to minimize, if not eliminate, any harmful effect on the environment or human health and safety from the emission of hydrocarbon gas before the completion of the repair; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a statement that the implementation of the plan is to begin within 30 days after the day on which the extension or deferral is granted.

Subsection.Text: If the application contains the information and documents referred to in subsection (3), the Minister must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an application referred to in subsection (1), extend the repair period or the period of time to complete the repair, as the case may be, for a period of no more than six months; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an application referred to in subsection (2), defer the scheduled day of the next planned shutdown for a period of no more than six months.

Subsection.Text: The Minister must renew an extension or deferral granted under subsection (4) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the operator provides the Minister with a renewal application that contains the information referred to in Schedule 1 and the following information and documents:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the information referred to in paragraphs (3)(c) and (d),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an application to renew an extension granted under paragraph (4)(a), documents that establish that, as of the making of the application, there are reasonable grounds to conclude that it is not technically feasible for the operator to complete the repair of the equipment component before the day on which the extended repair period ends or the additional time to complete the repair ends, as the case may be, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an application to renew a deferral granted under paragraph (4)(b), documents that establish that, as of the making of the application, there are reasonable grounds to conclude that it is not technically feasible for the operator to complete the repair of the equipment component before the day to which the next planned shutdown of the upstream oil and gas facility was deferred;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the application is provided

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an application to renew an extension referred to in paragraph (4)(a), no later than 45 days before the day on which the extended repair period ends or the additional time to complete the repair ends, as the case may be, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an application to renew a deferral referred to in paragraph (4)(b), no later than 45 days before the day to which the planned shutdown of the upstream oil and gas facility was deferred; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the extension or deferral, as the case may be, has not been previously renewed.

Subsection.Text: The Minister must refuse to grant an application referred to in this section if the Minister has reasonable grounds to believe that the operator has provided false or misleading information in the application.

The Minister must revoke an extension or deferral granted under subsection 8.16(4) or renewed under subsection 8.16(5) if the Minister has reasonable grounds to believe that the operator has provided false or misleading information in their application.
However, the Minister must not revoke the extension or deferral unless the Minister has provided the operator with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: written reasons for the proposed revocation; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an opportunity to be heard, by written representation, in respect of the proposed revocation.

Section.Text: A record must be made that sets out the following information respecting the inspections and fugitive emissions at an upstream oil and gas facility:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for each inspection,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: its date and time,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: whether it was a comprehensive inspection, a screening inspection or an annual inspection,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)

Subparagraph.Label: (v)

Paragraph.Label: (b)

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for each person who conducted a comprehensive or screening inspection,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: their name and contact information and the name and business address of their employer, if their employer is not the operator,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if, in accordance with paragraph 8.1(2)(b), a comprehensive inspection was not carried out at the facility

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the volume, expressed in m3, of crude oil produced at the facility in the previous calendar year, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the combined volume, expressed in m3, of hydrocarbon gas produced and received at the facility in the previous calendar year;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if, in accordance with subsection 8.1(3) or paragraph 8.11(2)(b), a comprehensive inspection or screening inspection was not carried out at the facility, the temperature that, on the day before the scheduled day of the inspection, was forecasted for the facility’s location on that scheduled day; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: for each fugitive emission detected,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the unique identifier, if any, assigned to the emission by the operator,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the equipment component that emitted the hydrocarbon gas and the location of that equipment component,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the date on which the emission was detected,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the date on which the emission ended,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the flow rate, expressed in kg/h, of the emission before repair of the equipment component, if determined,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: if the equipment component cannot be repaired while it is operating, the day of the next planned shutdown of the facility and the calculations that support scheduling the shutdown on that day,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: if a measure referred to in subsection 8.15(4) is taken to reduce the flow rate of the emission to less than 10 kg/h, the flow rate of the emission, expressed in kg/h, after that measure was taken,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the repair of the equipment component was deferred in accordance with subsection 8.15(6), the calculations that were used to identify the date until which the repair can be deferred, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: for each equipment component that is repaired, the method that was used to verify the repair.

Section.Text: Section 45.1 of the Regulations and the heading “Application” before it are repealed.
The Regulations are amended by adding the following after section 45.1:

Subsection.Text: The destruction of hydrocarbon gas at an upstream oil and gas facility, other than destruction that is necessary to avoid serious risk to human health or safety arising from an emergency situation, must be supported by an engineering study that concludes that use of the hydrocarbon gas to produce useful heat or energy is not feasible in the circumstances.

The engineering study must be reassessed every 12 months by an engineer and if the conclusion referred to in subsection (1) can no longer be supported, the destruction of hydrocarbon gas at the facility must cease.
Hydrocarbon gas destruction equipment, other than a catalytic oxidation system, that is used at an upstream oil and gas facility must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a combustion system that, when hydrocarbon gas is routed to that system,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: maintains the stable combustion of hydrocarbon gas without generating any visible emission, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: has a carbon conversion efficiency of at least 98%; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be operated and maintained in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations or, if they are not available, industry standards and best practices.

Subsection.Text: If the combustion system referred to in paragraph (1)(a) does not have an automatic flame failure detection system, the hydrocarbon gas destruction equipment must be visually inspected at least once every seven days to ensure that stable combustion of hydrocarbon gas is being maintained.
A catalytic oxidation system that is used at an upstream oil and gas facility for the purpose of hydrocarbon gas destruction must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be operated such that hydrocarbon gas is not routed to the system when the catalyst temperature is below that recommended by the equipment manufacturer; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be operated and maintained in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations.

Subsection.Text: If destruction of hydrocarbon gas occurs at an upstream oil and gas facility, a record must be made that contains

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the engineering study referred to in subsection 46(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: as applicable, a copy of the conclusions of any reassessment of that study performed in accordance with subsection 46(2).

Subsection.Text: The following records must be made respecting the hydrocarbon gas destruction equipment that is located at the facility:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a record that indicates whether the equipment consists of a combustion system or catalytic oxidation system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case where the equipment consists of a combustion system,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a record that indicates whether it has an automatic flame failure detection system and how the flame will be relit if it fails, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the combustion system does not have an automatic flame failure detection system, a record of each visual inspection performed in accordance with subsection 47(2); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a record that indicates how the equipment meets the requirements of subsection 47(1) or (3), as applicable, and that contains a description of how the equipment is operated and maintained, including the manufacturer’s recommendations — or, if they are not available — a list of the industry standards and best practices for its operation and maintenance.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), hydrocarbon gas must not be vented from an upstream oil and gas facility.
Hydrocarbon gas may be vented from the facility if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is vented as part of planned equipment maintenance or a planned temporary depressurization of equipment or a pipeline and measures are taken to minimize the volume of hydrocarbon gas that is vented;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is necessary to avoid serious risk to human health or safety arising from an emergency situation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the heating value of the hydrocarbon gas or its flow rate are insufficient to sustain continuous destruction of the gas by hydrocarbon gas destruction equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the use of hydrocarbon gas destruction equipment or hydrocarbon gas conservation equipment would prolong an interruption of the hydrocarbon gas supply to the public; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: crude oil is produced at the facility and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: operations at the facility began before January 1, 2028,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the calendar year before the one in which the venting is to occur, the volume of crude oil produced at the facility did not exceed 600 m3 and the total volume of hydrocarbon gas vented from the facility did not exceed 12 000 m3,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the venting is not from a pneumatic device that uses pressurized gas to generate mechanical energy, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: measures are taken to minimize the volume of hydrocarbon gas that is vented, such as the conservation or destruction of the gas.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (2), no more than 12 000 m3 of hydrocarbon gas may be vented in a calendar year from an upstream oil and gas facility referred to in paragraph (2)(e).

Section.Text: A record must be made that sets out the following information respecting the venting of hydrocarbon gas from an upstream oil and gas facility:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for each instance of venting referred to in paragraphs 49(2)(a) to (d),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date, time and duration of the venting,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: identification of the equipment component that is the source of the venting,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the flow rate of the vented hydrocarbon gas, expressed in kg/h, under standard conditions,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the circumstances leading up to the venting and the reasons for it, including identification of the exception referred to in subsection 49(2) that is to be relied on and an explanation of why it is applicable in the circumstances, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the measures that were taken to minimize the volume of the vented hydrocarbon gas; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of venting referred to in paragraph 49(2)(e),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the volume of crude oil, expressed in m3, that was produced at the facility in the previous calendar year,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the volume of hydrocarbon gas, expressed in m3, that was vented from facility in the previous calendar year, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the measures that were taken to minimize the volume of vented hydrocarbon gas.

Heading.Label: PART 2
Heading.TitleText: Upstream Oil and Gas Facilities Using an Emission Monitoring System

Subsection.Text: After providing the notice referred to in subsection 2.2(2), the operator must ensure that the facility emission intensity for the upstream oil and gas facility, as calculated by an engineer, remains less than its facility emission reference standard.
The facility emission intensity and facility emission rate for the facility must be updated annually and after

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: each analysis that is conducted under subsection 53.2(2); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any physical change to the facility or change to its operation that would affect, by 10% or more, the volume of the facility’s hydrocarbon gas emissions or the volume of hydrocarbon gas that is produced or processed at the facility or transported from it.

Subsection.Text: A facility emission rate that is updated, including in accordance with subsection (2), must be adjusted to include any change in the volume of hydrocarbon gas emissions from the facility, expressed in kg/h, that an engineer estimates will occur in the 365-day period following a physical change to the facility or a change to its operation that has occurred since the day on which the rate was last determined.
A record must be made that sets out the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the facility emission intensity and facility emission rate for the upstream oil and gas facility on the day specified in the notice provided under subsection 2.2(2); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: each update to its facility emission intensity and facility emission rate, the date of the update and the reason for it.

Subsection.Text: An emission monitoring system must be operating at all times, except for any period during which all or part of the system is undergoing preventive maintenance.
The preventive maintenance must not be performed during any period in which an emission of hydrocarbon gas is planned or expected to occur at the upstream oil and gas facility.
An emission monitoring system must meet the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its sensors and other equipment must

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: be capable, under controlled laboratory conditions, of detecting hydrocarbon gas emissions that have a total flow rate of 1 kg/h or more, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: be placed at locations where they can detect hydrocarbon gas emissions at the facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its sensors must take readings

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a Type 1 facility, at least once every 15 minutes, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a Type 2 facility or an inactive facility, at least once every 12 hours;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it must record each reading taken under paragraph (b); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: it must generate an alert when the total flow rate of hydrocarbon gas emissions detected at the facility exceeds the facility emission rate by 1 kg/h or more.

Subsection.Text: All sensors and other equipment that constitute the emission monitoring system must be calibrated in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations such that their measurements have a maximum margin of error of ±20%.

Subject to subsections (2) and (3), an annual inspection for hydrocarbon gas emissions at an upstream oil and gas facility must be conducted once per calendar year, with no less than 180 days having elapsed since the date of the last annual inspection, by an auditor who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is independent of the operator and owner of the facility that is to be inspected; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has knowledge of and experience with emission detection instruments.

Subsection.Text: An annual inspection is not required to be conducted at the upstream oil and gas facility in any calendar year in which an annual inspection is conducted at the facility under subsection 8.12(1).
An annual inspection is not required to include the inspection of an equipment component if that inspection would pose a serious risk to human health or safety.

An annual inspection must be conducted using methods that, under standard conditions, provide a 90% or greater probability of detecting hydrocarbon gas emissions at the facility that have a total flow rate of 10 kg/h or more.
A record must be made that sets out the following information respecting each annual inspection:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its date and time;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the auditor who conducted the inspection, along with the name and business address of their employer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the methodology and equipment used;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: information respecting the calibration of each instrument used;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether hydrocarbon gas emissions were detected; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if hydrocarbon gas emissions were detected,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: their total flow rate, expressed in kg/h,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the unique identifier, if any, assigned to those emissions by the operator, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a list of the measures that were taken to reduce those emissions, if any.

Subsection.Text: If the total flow rate of hydrocarbon gas emissions detected at an upstream oil and gas facility is higher than its facility emission rate by 1 kg/h or more, the total flow rate must be reduced to less than 1 kg/h above the facility emission rate as soon as feasible, but in any case, by no later than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the total flow rate is higher than the facility emission rate by 1 kg/h or more, but less than 10 kg/h higher than that rate, 30 days after the day on which the emissions are detected;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the total flow rate is higher than the facility emission rate by 10 kg/h or more but less than 100 kg/h higher than that rate, seven days after the day on which the emissions are detected; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the total flow rate is higher than the facility emission rate by 100 kg/h or more, 24 hours after the emissions are detected.

Subsection.Text: An analysis must be conducted in respect of each instance when the total flow rate of the hydrocarbon gas emissions detected at the upstream oil and gas facility is higher than its facility emission rate by 10 kg/h or more.
A record must be made that sets out the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date, time and duration of each instance when the emission monitoring system is not in operation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for each instance when the total flow rate of hydrocarbon gas emissions at the upstream oil and gas facility was higher than its facility emission rate by 1 kg/h or more,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the maximum total flow rate of the emissions, expressed in kg/h, if known,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the date and time when the emissions were detected,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the date and time when the total flow rate of the emissions was reduced to less than 1 kg/h above the facility emission rate,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a list of the measures that were taken to reduce the total flow rate of the emissions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the period, if any, during which the facility was shut down; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the results of each analysis conducted under subsection (2).

Section.Text: On or before June 30 in each year, an annual report must be provided to the Minister that contains the following information and documents in respect of the upstream oil and gas facility for the preceding calendar year:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: with respect to the annual inspection of the facility,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: as applicable, a copy of the record referred to in subsection 53.1(5) or a copy of the information referred to in paragraphs 8.18(a), (b) and (f), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: every reading of the total flow rate of hydrocarbon gas emissions at the facility that was taken and recorded by the emission monitoring system during the annual inspection;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the information referred to in paragraphs 53.2(3)(b) and (c) respecting the total flow rate of hydrocarbon gas emissions during the calendar year at the facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: each update to its facility emission intensity and facility emission rate, the calculations that support the update, the date of the update and the reason for it; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the last facility emission intensity and facility emission rate calculated in the calendar year preceding the calendar year for which the report is provided.
